The bipartisan #COVID19 emergency aid bill has improved dramatically in the last few days—here's some of what's included. https://t.co/fbZwVdkYwz

This bipartisan bill has improved dramatically in the last few days, and while it’s still far from perfect—it’s desperately needed right now to save lives, slow the spread of this #COVID19 pandemic, and provide relief to American families.

I’ve been pushing for direct cash payments to get money to the people who need it most & to help stimulate our economy—the bill provides $1,200 per adult & $500 per child for most, and there’s no minimum earning requirement that would've excluded some of our most vulnerable.

.@SenateDems & I fought for money for small business grants —the bill now includes $350 billion in loan forgiveness grants to small businesses and nonprofits to maintain existing workforce & help pay for other expenses like rent, mortgage, and utilities.

.@SenateDems & I fought for the largest expansion of UI benefits in decades—the bill now increases benefits by up to $600 per week, eliminates the “waiting week” requirement & expands unemployment benefits for part time, self employed & “gig economy” workers.

.@SenateDems & I fought for a “Marshall Plan for Hospitals”—the bill now includes $150 billion for health workers & hospitals including a new $100 billion program to provide direct aid to those on the frontlines & billions for our strategic stockpile of medical supplies.

The bipartisan $2 trillion #StimulusPlan puts people first:
✅Provides billions of dollars for health workers & hospitals
✅Protects workers & small business owners
✅Largest expansion of unemployment benefits in decades
✅Sends direct cash payments to Americans

.@SenateDemocrats & I fought for money for small business grants —the bill now includes $350 billion in loan forgiveness grants to small businesses & nonprofits to maintain existing workforce & help pay for other expenses like rent, mortgage & utilities.

.@SenateDemocrats & I fought for the largest expansion of UI benefits in decades—the bill now increases benefits by up to $600 per week, eliminates the “waiting week” requirement & expands unemployment benefits for part time, self employed & “gig economy” workers.

.@SenateDemocrats & I fought for a “Marshall Plan for Hospitals”—the bill now includes $150 billion for health workers & hospitals including a new $100 billion program to provide direct aid to those on the frontlines & billions for our strategic stockpile of medical supplies.

Health care is a human right—and we all need to be working together to expand access to affordable, quality health coverage for all Americans.
Without the #ACA, states wouldn’t have been able to expand their Medicaid programs, which is going to be a key resource for many as we respond to and recover from this pandemic.

Without the #ACA, people with preexisting conditions would have difficulty getting the coverage they need to fight the #COVID19 virus—and many of us might not be able to get care now or in the future because of annual and lifetime caps that were allowed before the law was passed.

Because of the #ACA:
- Millions of people with pre-existing conditions can no longer be denied coverage.
- Tens of millions of uninsured people have gained insurance.
- And countless others have high quality care that covers essential health benefits and preventive care.

Today, as we face a public health crisis, quality, affordable health coverage is more important than ever. So I wanted to take some time to recognize the 10th anniversary of the #AffordableCareAct—one of the most impactful pieces of legislation in our lifetime. https://t.co/rHI8AcgFHX
Thank you, @BarackObama. https://t.co/niV6r3aRh8

In mere days, we've gone from life as normal to implementing dramatic changes in how we work, interact, and live. The impact on our economy—and to the millions of American workers and businesses who underpin it—will be enormous and require a large-scale, aggressive response.

Here in New Jersey, we have some of the strongest paid family and sick leave protections in the country—but for millions of Americans across our nation, staying home when you’re sick is simply not an option. We need paid sick leave at the federal level.

Remember: we’re all in this together.
